Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A pan-Arctic, storm-by-storm isotopic investigation of the influence of Arctic sea ice on precipitation - a crucial link in the coupled climate system
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will quantify the relationship between the ice-free area of the Arctic Ocean and surrounding seas, and evaporation and precipitation in the Arctic region. The methodology uses isotopic compositions of storm-by-storm precipitation samples, pan-Arctic meteorological data, and numerical modeling. Precipitation samples will be collected at nine Arctic observatories, and by three high schools in Greenland. Samples will be analyzed for D/H and 18O/16O ratios. The track of a given storm will be reconstructed using reanalysis data and a Lagrangian trajectory algorithm. The moisture sources are then localized, and the δ18O, δD and d-excess of the source vapor are calculated using the sea surface temperature, relative humidity and wind speed. The sea ice area transected by each storm will be obtained using high-resolution satellite products. A two-dimensional (2D) model of the atmospheric moisture cycle will be used to compute the isotopic composition of precipitation for each storm at each site using reanalysis values of meteorological variables at the times and regions identified by the Lagrangian back trajectory, and assuming a range of sea ice concentrations. The sea ice concentration that best fits our isotopic measurements is then compared with the satellite sea ice data. The isotope data will thus yield, via the 2D model, the sensitivity of Arctic evaporation and precipitation to ice area. The project will yield a quantitative understanding of the links among sea ice, and moisture sources and amounts of Arctic precipitation, which comprise an important part of climate dynamics on a wide range of time scales. The results will be pertinent to the interpretation of ice core data, ice age dynamics, sudden climate change, and global warming. This project also intends to integrate research with education and outreach, which will directly benefit participating Arctic communities. The project aims to improve community understanding of how climate change research is done, by providing Arctic students with new knowledge and skills, and by inspiring them to pursue advanced studies. At the same time, the PI's will benefit from learning traditional methods of observing, categorizing, and forecasting weather and climate from the communities participating in the study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sea ice is an important part of the global climate system. Its effect of sea ice on albedo (how much fraction of sun light is reflected) and the associated radiation balance is well known. The more sea ice area, the larger the ocean surface is white that strongly reflects sunlight, and the colder it becomes, and then even more sea ice grows. Another effect of sea ice is through its influence on the hydrological cycle. With a reduction of sea ice area, more evaporation occurs from the ice-free sea surface, and more precipitation falls in the Arctic. Depending on whether the precipitation fall as snow or rain, it may changes the land surface albedo and thus radiation balance. Our project, referred to as iisPacs (Isotopic Investigation of Sea ice and Precipitation in the Arctic Climate System), is designed to quantify this sea ice - precipitation link using the sea ice observations, and pan Arctic precipitation collections.

The study has shown that with increasing ice-free area of the Arctic seas, a greater fraction of moisture falling as rain or snow in the Arctic would be derived from the northern local areas. We have estimated how this hydrological change would result in an increase in the total annual Arctic precipitation, and a change in the atmospheric energy budget. The study concluded that the sea ice - precipitation link likely causes a change in radiation balance with a magnitude similar to that caused by doubled CO2 concentration in the atmosphere.

This work has several broader impacts. The result will affect the climate predications in the next a few decades by contributing to our understanding of climate dynamics. Through the sampling campaign, the project enhanced research infrastructure in several Arctic research stations in Greenland, Norway, Russia and Canada, and trained technical personnel in these stations for collecting precipitation samples that can be analyzed for isotopic compositions. Five graduate and seven undergraduate students participated in this project. They have learned a wide range of skills, including archiving samples, maintaining the database, operating sophisticated analytical equipment, and, in the case of graduate students, interpreting, presenting and reporting scientific results.
